TUESDAY, APRIL 12, 1932

Banquet Season
DESPITE the fact that we believe that the pre-banquet freshmen-sophomore warfare is somewhat incongruoqs with the general
campus conservativeness at the
Hopkins, we nevertheless heartily
endorse banquet season for the
chief reason that it is the only surviving undergraduate tradition at
Homewood.
It is only in the spring of the
year on this occasion that the utter
soberness of the campus is broken
for about ten days. And then the
underclassmen, together with their
fellow upperclassmen, sink back
into the customary placidity.
We make a single appeal to the
members and officers of both the
freshman and sophomore classes :
make it your duty to see to it that
no serious injuries to individuals,
that no destruction of property, and
that no vandalism of any sort
occurs.

Freedom Of Press?
BECAUSE of the fearlessness
that marked him as a man, Reed
Harris, editor-in-chief of the Spectator, campus daily of Columbia
University, has been expelled. College newspaperdom has lost another
splendid editor through the commission of a great mistake made
by a college administration.
Following a campaign against
"semi-professionalism" in football,
which brought him national fame,
Harris has been expelled two
months prior to his graduation because he has written editorials
bearing ,a n excess of "insinuation,
innuendo; and misrepresentation."
Thus the Columbia senior has
been robbed of his degree, the
Spectator has been robbed of an
inimitable editor, Harris has been
made an example of by the administration.
Unaware of the facts in the case
or of the whole truth of the matter,
we, nevertheless, assume that Harris knew too much about the alleged
football "racket" at Columbia and,
having made the Columbia administration squirm, was consequently
expelled from the university without being given an opportunity to
be heard in his own defense.
An examination of the quotes
from his editorials which the press
carried will reveal that nothing
was blindly charged by him and
that nothing was said to warrant
his expulsion at so near a time to
graduation.

Most assuredly, the penalty for
IIarris's fearlessness was too stringent.
We admire him and we
sincerely regret the passing of a.
truly great college newspaper editor. Vi,T e pay tribute to him as the
adherent to John Jay Chapman's
advice: "Do what you will, but
speak out always. Be shunned, be

hated, be ridiculed, be scared, but
don't be gagged."
____

A Miserable Failure
\'\TITH the passing of the credit
system; effective in September, the
fate of the R. 0. T. C. on the
campus hang-; in balance. With
the incentive to take two years of
R. 0. T. C.-the six points giventhe removed degeneration of that
organization is almost inevitable.
How many will be content next
academic year to drag guns around
two hours each week on the quadrangle before Gilman Hall without
being rewarded with credits toward
graduation? In the answer to that
query lies one of the chief reasons
for the abolition of the R. 0. T. C.
at the Hopkins: students have been
lured to take the military science
course by the credits offered and
have not joined the organization
because of the physical and mental
benefits which might be derived
from it.
We predict that the number of
those taking R. 0. T. C. next year
will be decreased, provided only
that the physical training course
here is improved, organized, made
attractive, and raised from the
farcial state in which it now exists
on the campus. Because of its inefficiency and general absurdity,
we admit that the physical training
course, as it exists, will fail to draw
many students away from R. 0.
T. C., despite the fact credits have
been obliterated for drill.
Miserably the R. 0. T. C. has
failed in one of its alleged purposes: to improve a young man's
physique and to give him a better
carriage. One need not take a second ·glance to assure one's self that
many students who drag guns
around two hours weekly are sorely
wanting in especially the latter.
Military drill is restricted exercise, artificial, and monotonous. It
is not meant for physical training
and is not used for that purpose at
\i\T est Point or in the Army. As has
been pointed out by those who
know, even regular military institutions have physical training for
body-building and to correct the
bad effects of military drill which
has as its primary purpose military
discipline.
Educators point out that the U.
S. army has no college of physical
education to give the scientific
training necessary for modem
teachers of physical education.
Military
instructors,
therefore,
cannot adequately present the alleged physical training side of R.

0. T. C.

C. Ritchie, of Maryland, candidate
for the presidential nomination, as
the only man of all the aspirants
who would be capable enough to
stand at the helm of a nation
trembling beneath the pressure of
economic depression.
Ritchie, unlike other Democratic
contenders, has been conspicuously
plain-spoken and has distinguished
his campaign by frank statements
of specific issues. Other candidates
for the presidential nomination
rely upon support through the mechanics of politics and display extraordinary agility in concealing
their policies. Pussyfooting has
repeatedly marked campaigns conducted by contenders for the nomination in the past four administrations.
The nation's condition demands
now a real leader who will place
policy and the welfare of the country above the customary political
jockeying. In Ritchie there is the
leader that the United States so
vitally needs. In him the Democrats indubitably have a truly big'
man. This fact is recognized by
politicians and the press throughout the nation.

The Band Wagon
The stage and loft of Ford's
Theatre is this week undergoing
the nece?sary alteration to accommodate the · double revolving stages
used in Max Gordon's elaborate review, The Band Wagon. The procluction is scheduled for April 25,
and will be given by the original
New York cast, headed by Fred
Astaire, Frank Morgan, and Helen
Broderick.
Modern Medley
Diana Rogge's prize-winning
play, Modern Medley, will be produced by ithe Homewood Playshop
this week, under the direction of
N. Bryllion Fagin. The cast stars
Helena Gambrill, Jeanette auters,
and William Wrightson. The play
is reviewed by Mr. Ewing elsewhere in this paper.
Too True to be Good
This latest opus of George Bernard Shaw has given rise to confticting opinions among the critics.
Percy Hammond of the Herald(O.) Tribitne feels that there is life in

In season and out he has stood
out as a shining example of at
least one man in public life who
. knows what it is all about and
who has never hesitated to speak
· out to the public and tell it where
he stands. There is none of the
pussy-footer or political Charlatan
about him. He knows that government was not created to own
and exploit but to serve the people
and all of his public life he has
been preaching and practicing that
doctrine. No one has ever found
him blowing hot and cold or sidestepping or evading. Were he
nominated he would, of course, be
elected.
Here's hoping that the great
party of Jefferson which knows
nothing about Jefferson except his
name, may relapse into an unexpected fit of sanity and nominate
in the person of Governor Ritchie
their strongest and greatest man..
Hitting the target, Ritchie declares that there's a major thing
wrong with the nation: there's too
much talk. Above "the din of distracting discord," as the times has
been termed, the Maryland Governor booms forth clearly and concisely his practical suggestions for'
'the general betterment of the condition of the United States, which
he has carefully analyzed.
Willing to m,ake known his
worthwhile views on issues of
national significance, Ritchie, an
able administrator and a man of
very impressive bearing, has been
carrying on his campaign for the
presidential nomination forthrightly
with a cour.age and force which
has marked his four terms at the
head of the Free State.
Hardly any unbiased, sane, liberal-minded Democrat or Republican can disagree with the view
expressed by the Chicago Tribune :
Gov. Ritchie is making the most
important contribution to straight
thinking by the American people,
and his service to political integrity is worthy of the Nation's
gratitude.
A refreshing contrast to any
other candidate for the nomination,
Ritchie, a Johns· Hopkins graduate, should be considered by the
delegates to the Democratic convention. He towers, most assuredly, above not only his fellow contenders but also many who have
sat in the White House.

campus R. 0. T. C. unit until adequate facilities are available for

The Johns Hopkins Press recently announced its latest publication, entitled "The Kings Bench
Masters and English Interlocutory
Practice" by E. S. Greenbaum, a
Research Associate in the Law Institute and L. S. Reade, Barristerat-Law.
The introduction is written by
Professor Oliphant. The object of
the book is to describe some of the
more important features of English
interlocutory practice and the work
of the Kings Bench masters. The
authors attempt to sufficiently explain the function of the masters
and some of their characteristic
work, so as to enable American
lawyers to compare English procedure with practice in this country.

"A Solvent Religion in a Bankrupt Age" will be the subject of

6 P. M. today will also be announced.
Union Hebrew College Grad
Rabbi Wolsey is in charge of
Congregation Rocleph Shalom in
Philadelphia and is a member of
the American Academy of Political and Social Sciences and the
American Oriental SO'ciety. He
is a graduate of Union Hebrew
College and has done graduate
work at the University of Chicago and Western Reserve University. He was formerly president of the Central Conference of
American Rabbis.
At a luncheon meeting of the
"Y" Cabinet at 12 :30, Rabbi Wolsey will talk on the subject of
Judaism, when he will explain the
fundamentals of that religions to
the Cabinet members.

of eight Supper Club meetings,
the last of which will be held May
3 as the installation dinner for
next year's Cabinet, with Arthur
Rugh, National Secretary for Religious Work of the Y. M. C. A.,
as the speaker.

TUESDAY, APRIL 12, 1932

Banquet Season
DESPITE the fact that we believe that the pre-banquet freshmen-sophomore warfare is somewhat incongruoqs with the general
campus conservativeness at the
Hopkins, we nevertheless heartily
endorse banquet season for the
chief reason that it is the only surviving undergraduate tradition at
Homewood.
It is only in the spring of the
year on this occasion that the utter
soberness of the campus is broken
for about ten days. And then the
underclassmen, together with their
fellow upperclassmen, sink back
into the customary placidity.
We make a single appeal to the
members and officers of both the
freshman and sophomore classes :
make it your duty to see to it that
no serious injuries to individuals,
that no destruction of property, and
that no vandalism of any sort
occurs.

Freedom Of Press?
BECAUSE of the fearlessness
that marked him as a man, Reed
Harris, editor-in-chief of the Spectator, campus daily of Columbia
University, has been expelled. College newspaperdom has lost another
splendid editor through the commission of a great mistake made
by a college administration.
Following a campaign against
"semi-professionalism" in football,
which brought him national fame,
Harris has been expelled two
months prior to his graduation because he has written editorials
bearing ,a n excess of "insinuation,
innuendo; and misrepresentation."
Thus the Columbia senior has
been robbed of his degree, the
Spectator has been robbed of an
inimitable editor, Harris has been
made an example of by the administration.
Unaware of the facts in the case
or of the whole truth of the matter,
we, nevertheless, assume that Harris knew too much about the alleged
football "racket" at Columbia and,
having made the Columbia administration squirm, was consequently
expelled from the university without being given an opportunity to
be heard in his own defense.
An examination of the quotes
from his editorials which the press
carried will reveal that nothing
was blindly charged by him and
that nothing was said to warrant
his expulsion at so near a time to
graduation.

Most assuredly, the penalty for
IIarris's fearlessness was too stringent.
We admire him and we
sincerely regret the passing of a.
truly great college newspaper editor. Vi,T e pay tribute to him as the
adherent to John Jay Chapman's
advice: "Do what you will, but
speak out always. Be shunned, be

hated, be ridiculed, be scared, but
don't be gagged."
____

A Miserable Failure
\'\TITH the passing of the credit
system; effective in September, the
fate of the R. 0. T. C. on the
campus hang-; in balance. With
the incentive to take two years of
R. 0. T. C.-the six points giventhe removed degeneration of that
organization is almost inevitable.
How many will be content next
academic year to drag guns around
two hours each week on the quadrangle before Gilman Hall without
being rewarded with credits toward
graduation? In the answer to that
query lies one of the chief reasons
for the abolition of the R. 0. T. C.
at the Hopkins: students have been
lured to take the military science
course by the credits offered and
have not joined the organization
because of the physical and mental
benefits which might be derived
from it.
We predict that the number of
those taking R. 0. T. C. next year
will be decreased, provided only
that the physical training course
here is improved, organized, made
attractive, and raised from the
farcial state in which it now exists
on the campus. Because of its inefficiency and general absurdity,
we admit that the physical training
course, as it exists, will fail to draw
many students away from R. 0.
T. C., despite the fact credits have
been obliterated for drill.
Miserably the R. 0. T. C. has
failed in one of its alleged purposes: to improve a young man's
physique and to give him a better
carriage. One need not take a second ·glance to assure one's self that
many students who drag guns
around two hours weekly are sorely
wanting in especially the latter.
Military drill is restricted exercise, artificial, and monotonous. It
is not meant for physical training
and is not used for that purpose at
\i\T est Point or in the Army. As has
been pointed out by those who
know, even regular military institutions have physical training for
body-building and to correct the
bad effects of military drill which
has as its primary purpose military
discipline.
Educators point out that the U.
S. army has no college of physical
education to give the scientific
training necessary for modem
teachers of physical education.
Military
instructors,
therefore,
cannot adequately present the alleged physical training side of R.

0. T. C.

C. Ritchie, of Maryland, candidate
for the presidential nomination, as
the only man of all the aspirants
who would be capable enough to
stand at the helm of a nation
trembling beneath the pressure of
economic depression.
Ritchie, unlike other Democratic
contenders, has been conspicuously
plain-spoken and has distinguished
his campaign by frank statements
of specific issues. Other candidates
for the presidential nomination
rely upon support through the mechanics of politics and display extraordinary agility in concealing
their policies. Pussyfooting has
repeatedly marked campaigns conducted by contenders for the nomination in the past four administrations.
The nation's condition demands
now a real leader who will place
policy and the welfare of the country above the customary political
jockeying. In Ritchie there is the
leader that the United States so
vitally needs. In him the Democrats indubitably have a truly big'
man. This fact is recognized by
politicians and the press throughout the nation.

Too True to be Good
This latest opus of George Bernard Shaw has given rise to confticting opinions among the critics.
Percy Hammond of the Herald(O.) Tribitne feels that there is life in

In season and out he has stood
out as a shining example of at
least one man in public life who
. knows what it is all about and
who has never hesitated to speak
· out to the public and tell it where
he stands. There is none of the
pussy-footer or political Charlatan
about him. He knows that government was not created to own
and exploit but to serve the people
and all of his public life he has
been preaching and practicing that
doctrine. No one has ever found
him blowing hot and cold or sidestepping or evading. Were he
nominated he would, of course, be
elected.
Here's hoping that the great
party of Jefferson which knows
nothing about Jefferson except his
name, may relapse into an unexpected fit of sanity and nominate
in the person of Governor Ritchie
their strongest and greatest man..
Hitting the target, Ritchie declares that there's a major thing
wrong with the nation: there's too
much talk. Above "the din of distracting discord," as the times has
been termed, the Maryland Governor booms forth clearly and concisely his practical suggestions for'
'the general betterment of the condition of the United States, which
he has carefully analyzed.
Willing to m,ake known his
worthwhile views on issues of
national significance, Ritchie, an
able administrator and a man of
very impressive bearing, has been
carrying on his campaign for the
presidential nomination forthrightly
with a cour.age and force which
has marked his four terms at the
head of the Free State.
Hardly any unbiased, sane, liberal-minded Democrat or Republican can disagree with the view
expressed by the Chicago Tribune :
Gov. Ritchie is making the most
important contribution to straight
thinking by the American people,
and his service to political integrity is worthy of the Nation's
gratitude.
A refreshing contrast to any
other candidate for the nomination,
Ritchie, a Johns· Hopkins graduate, should be considered by the
delegates to the Democratic convention. He towers, most assuredly, above not only his fellow contenders but also many who have
sat in the White House.

Medical Library, 1900 E. Monument Street. This i;:xhibition will

recently donated to the University by Dr. Henry Barton Jacobs.

WEEK OF APRIL 11

WEEK OF APRIL 11 ·

The Johns Hopkins Press recently announced its latest publication, entitled "The Kings Bench
Masters and English Interlocutory
Practice" by E. S. Greenbaum, a
Research Associate in the Law Institute and L. S. Reade, Barristerat-Law.
The introduction is written by
Professor Oliphant. The object of
the book is to describe some of the
more important features of English
interlocutory practice and the work
of the Kings Bench masters. The
authors attempt to sufficiently explain the function of the masters
and some of their characteristic
work, so as to enable American
lawyers to compare English procedure with practice in this country.

"A Solvent Religion in a Bankrupt Age" will be the subject of
Rabbi Louis Wolsey at the April
meeting of the University Supper
Club tonight at 6 :30 o'clock. At
this time the results of the election of officers of the Y. M. C. A.
being conducted from noon until
6 P. M. today will also be announced.
Union Hebrew College Grad
Rabbi Wolsey is in charge of
Congregation Rocleph Shalom in
Philadelphia and is a member of
the American Academy of Political and Social Sciences and the
American Oriental SO'ciety. He
is a graduate of Union Hebrew
College and has done graduate
work at the University of Chicago and Western Reserve University. He was formerly president of the Central Conference of
American Rabbis.
At a luncheon meeting of the
"Y" Cabinet at 12 :30, Rabbi Wolsey will talk on the subject of
Judaism, when he will explain the
fundamentals of that religions to
the Cabinet members.
Seventh Of Series
This is the seventh in the series
of eight Supper Club meetings,
the last of which will be held May
3 as the installation dinner for
next year's Cabinet, with Arthur
Rugh, National Secretary for Religious Work of the Y. M. C. A.,
as the speaker.

should have come to such a pass
